Article: Lab-on-a-chip microfluidic devices and other technologies at the nexus of biochemistry and electrical engineering are vulnerable to attacks, fraud, hacks, intellectual property theft and counterfeiting. Presenters at the conference explored threats to digital microfluidics, an electronics process using Pacman-like manipulations of microscopic drops of fluid in tiny capillaries etched on silicon chips.
